message_1: Consider the topological space X = {a, b, c} with topology T = {∅,{a},{b},{a,b},{a,c},{b,c},X}. Find the interior, closure, and boundary of the set A = {a, b}.
message_2:
To find the interior, closure, and boundary of the set A = {a, b}, we will analyze the topology T and the given set A.

1. Interior of A:
The interior of a set A, denoted as Int(A), is the union of all open sets contained in A. In this case, the open sets contained in A are {a}, {b}, and {a, b}. Therefore, the interior of A is the union of these sets:

Int(A) = {a} ∪ {b} ∪ {a, b} = {a, b}

2. Closure of A:
The closure of a set A, denoted as Cl(A), is the intersection of all closed sets containing A. A closed set is the complement of an open set. In this topology, the closed sets are {∅, {c}, {a, c}, {b, c}, X}. The closed sets containing A are {a, c}, {b, c}, and X. Therefore, the closure of A is the intersection of these sets:

Cl(A) = {a, c} ∩ {b, c} ∩ X = {a, b}

3. Boundary of A:
The boundary of a set A, denoted as ∂A, is the difference between the closure of A and the interior of A:

∂A = Cl(A) - Int(A)

From our previous calculations, we have Cl(A) = {a, b} and Int(A) = {a, b}. Therefore, the boundary of A is:

∂A = {a, b} - {a, b} = ∅

In conclusion, for the set A = {a, b} in the topological space X with topology T, we have:

- Interior of A: Int(A) = {a, b}
- Closure of A: Cl(A) = {a, b}
- Boundary of A: ∂A = ∅
